description:
Reticuloendotheliosis virus (REV) is a member of the Retroviridae family, specifically belonging to the genus Gammaretrovirus. It is an avian virus that primarily infects and replicates within the cells of the reticuloendothelial system, which includes cells such as macrophages, lymphocytes, and endothelial cells.

The virus genome consists of a single-stranded, positive-sense RNA molecule that is approximately 8-9 kilobases in length. The viral genome encodes the typical retroviral structural proteins, including the Gag, Pol, and Env proteins, as well as additional regulatory proteins that are essential for the virus's replication and pathogenesis.

REV is known to cause a variety of diseases in infected birds, including neoplastic disorders, immunosuppression, and neurological disorders. The virus can be transmitted both horizontally, through direct contact or exposure to contaminated environments, as well as vertically, from infected parent birds to their offspring.

The virus is an important model system for studying retroviral biology, as well as the mechanisms of virus-induced immunosuppression and oncogenesis in avian species. Understanding the biology and pathogenesis of REV has broader implications for the study of related retroviruses and their interactions with host immune systems.
